name: Who is that Doggie on the TV? Trivia Game | Famous Animals | 10 Questions

questions.text: Stephen King helped greatly in writing the screenplay for his book turned horror movie about a rabies-stricken St. Bernard who preys on a family. What name did Stephen King give to the St. Bernard?
questions.explanation:
Cujo.

	Cujo was played by five different St. Bernards, two mechanical heads, one man in costume, and one rottweiler. Dog toys belonging to the dogs in the movie were kept in the car to make the dogs attack the vehicle.

questions.text: How did Old Yeller die in the book and movie of the same name?
questions.explanation:
Shot.

	Old Yeller was a yellow labrador retriever and mastiff mix found in a field by a boy named Travis. When Old Yeller was attacked by a rabid wolf, he had to be put down by Travis for everyone's safety.

questions.text: What restaurant did Gidget the chihuahua advertise for by asking for her food in Spanish?
questions.explanation:
Taco Bell.

	Dinky was supposed to play in the Taco Bell commercial, but at the last minute was replaced with his on screen girlfriend Gidget. The voice that came from Gidget's mouth was Carlos Alazraqui. Her last TV appearance was as Bruiser's mom in the 2003 comedy, "Legally Blonde 2". Gidget passed away in 2009.

questions.text: In "The Adventures of Milo and Otis", what name did the pug go by in the movie?
questions.explanation:
Otis.

	"The Adventures of Milo and Otis" was a non-verbal movie about a cat and a dog on an adventure together. The movie was a remake of a Japanese movie made in 1989. The Japanese original took four years to make.

questions.text: What breed of dog was Marley from the movie, "Marley and Me"?
questions.explanation:
Labrador Retriever.

	Marley was owned by John and Jenny Grogan. The labrador retriever first became famous through John Grogan's book and later children's books. Twenty-two labrador retrievers were used to represent the fourteen years of Marley's life in the movie.

questions.text: There's no place like home for Terry whose most famous acting job was playing this dog in "The Wizard of Oz"?
questions.explanation:
Toto.

	Terry was a female Cairn Terrier whose name was changed to Toto in the credits of "The Wizard of Oz". Terry's first movie role was in the 1934 "Ready For Love". In her second role, she played along side Shirley Temple. For her role in "The Wizard of Oz", Terry was payed $125 dollars, more than most actors were paid for their roles in the movie. Terry died at the age of eleven.

questions.text: What animated family owned a greyhound named Santa's Little Helper?
questions.explanation:
The Simpsons.

	Santa's Little Helper was a greyhound that lost a race and was abandoned. Homer and his son Bart go to the race track trying to make some money for Christmas presents and find Santa's Little Helper. They take him home to be part of the family.

questions.text: Named after a classical musician in the movie of the same name, this St. Bernard came close to being called by a male body part by one of the children in the movie. What classical music name was given to the dog?
questions.explanation:
Beethoven.

	Beethoven was played by three separate dogs in the first movie that spawned several sequels. When the dog was first found by the family and named, the youngest daughter's name for the animal was thrown out due to the father not wanting to call it out every day. Beethoven was trained for this film by Buster Keaton's widow, Eleanor.

questions.text: Beasley played Hooch the dog in the 1989 comedy "Turner and Hooch" alongside co-star Tom Hanks. Hooch was a Dogue de Bordeaux, a famous breed from what country?
questions.explanation:
France.

	Beasley was born in Wisconsin to Peter Curley. He was bought and trained for the role of Hooch by Clint Rowe. A mechanical dog was built to look like Hooch for the shooting and subsequent death scene.

questions.text: What group of kids shared a dog they named Petey?
questions.explanation:
The Little Rascals (Our Gang).

	Pete the Pup was an American Staffordshire Terrier who played Petey in "The Little Rascals" until he was fired in 1932. In the 1994 remake of "The Little Rascals", Petey was played by an American Pit Bull Terrier.
